segments.text: Afternoon exercise session, day 88. Two hours mandatory to counteract bone and muscle loss. Let's get started.
First up, the ARED - Advanced Resistive Exercise Device. Starting with squats. Setting resistance to 120 kilograms.
In microgravity, your muscles atrophy fast without resistance training. We lose about 1 percent muscle mass per month if we don't work out.
Positioning my feet in the restraints. Without these, I'd just float away when I try to push. Okay, starting squats.
One... two... three... the resistance feels good. My legs are still sore from yesterday's session, but that's normal.
Four... five... six... I'm targeting three sets of fifteen. That's the protocol for maintaining leg strength.
Seven... eight... nine... breathing steady. In zero-g, even simple exercises feel different. No gravity to help you down.
Ten... eleven... twelve... Torres and Kim did great on the EVA this morning. Antenna bracket replaced successfully in 87 minutes.
Thirteen... fourteen... fifteen. First set complete. Resting for 60 seconds, then set two.
You know, people ask if exercise in space is easier because there's no gravity. It's not. The resistance is the same, but your body works differently.
Your cardiovascular system doesn't have to pump blood uphill against gravity. Your heart can get lazy if you're not careful.
Alright, rest is over. Starting set two. One... two... three... keeping form consistent.
Four... five... six... when I get back to Earth, the readjustment is going to be brutal. Everything will feel heavy.
Seven... eight... nine... astronauts who skip workouts can barely walk when they land. Some can't even stand up.
Ten... eleven... twelve... so yeah, two hours daily is non-negotiable. It's medical necessity disguised as exercise.
Thirteen... fourteen... fifteen. Set two done. One more set after a quick break.
The EVA today reminded me why we do all this preparation. One small bracket failure, and we lose critical communications capability.
Torres handled the repair perfectly. Kim's tether management was textbook. I was proud watching them work together.
Alright, final set. One... two... three... pushing through the fatigue.
Four... five... six... my quads are burning now. Good sign - means I'm working hard enough.
Seven... eight... nine... after squats, I'll do deadlifts, then upper body. Full-body workout to maintain overall strength.
Ten... eleven... twelve... almost there. Mind over muscle at this point.
Thirteen... fourteen... fifteen. Done! Squats complete. Wiping down the equipment. Next person needs a clean machine.
Now switching to deadlift position. Adjusting the bar restraint. Setting resistance to 140 kilograms for deadlifts.
Deadlifts are crucial for posterior chain - back, glutes, hamstrings. All the muscles that keep you upright on Earth.
Gripping the bar. Feet secured. Starting first set. One... two... three... feeling the pull through my entire back.
Four... five... six... we track all our exercise data. Medical monitors it to ensure we're maintaining bone density and muscle mass.
Seven... eight... nine... they'll do full body scans when we return. Compare before and after measurements.
Ten... eleven... twelve... long-duration missions, like Mars trips, will need even better exercise protocols.
Thirteen... fourteen... fifteen. First set of deadlifts complete. Two more to go, then upper body work.
Resting. Drinking water. Hydration is important - we lose fluids differently up here because of how blood distributes in microgravity.
This is the unglamorous part of being an astronaut. Two hours every day, sweating in a confined module, lifting weights.
But it's essential. Can't do the exciting stuff - EVAs, experiments, Earth observation - if my body breaks down.
Alright, back to work. Seventy-five more minutes of this, then I can shower. Well, sponge bath. We don't have showers up here.

environment.background_sounds: equipment hydraulics, breathing, metal clanking, fan noise
